title: 105_s155
content: The Act may be cited as the "Grant's Tomb National Monument Act of 1997". Ulysses S. Grant is recognized as a national hero for leading the Union Army to victory in the Civil War, serving as the 18th President of the United States, and advocating for the rights of freed slaves. The Act aims to recognize and honor Ulysses S. Grant as a general and former President, preserve Grant's Tomb National Monument, and educate future generations about his contributions to the United States. The Act defines key terms such as "monument" as Grant's Tomb National Monument, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "tomb" as the tomb of Ulysses S. Grant. It also includes provisions for the redesignation and administration of Grant's Tomb National Monument. Grant's Tomb National Monument, located in New York, is redesignated from General Grant National Memorial. The monument includes the tomb and surrounding plaza area. The Secretary will administer, repair, and promote the monument in accordance with the law. The Secretary will design and construct a visitors center at Grant's Tomb National Monument to aid in interpretation and maintain historical significance. The center will be established in consultation with the study commission and designed to be consistent with the site's architectural and historical intent without detracting from the historical interpretation and scenic views. The Secretary will acquire non-Federal lands within the monument through donation, purchase, or exchange. They may also lease or enter into cooperative agreements for managing non-Federal lands. Additionally, a study commission will be established. Establishment of a study commission of 7 persons, including members of the Grant Monument Association, community representatives, and citizens with relevant expertise. Government employees are ineligible, members serve without pay, and designate a chair. The study commission, consisting of 7 members, is tasked with reviewing security, maintenance, and restoration plans for the monument. They are also responsible for submitting reports to the Secretary and Congress. Administrative support services are provided by the Secretary upon request. The study commission, comprised of 7 members, reviews security, maintenance, and restoration plans for the monument. They submit reports to the Secretary and Congress on repair progress. Within 180 days of their first meeting, they provide a study to the Secretary with proposed measures for improvement based on original architect plans. The study commission reviews plans for monument repair and improvement, submitting a final plan to Congress within 90 days for completion by April 27, 1999. The plan must align with the study, except for aspects deemed unreasonable, inconsistent with the site's intent, or detracting from its historical significance. The study commission's final plan for monument repair and improvement must align with the site's architectural and historical intent, not detract from its historical interpretation or scenic views, and be consistent with the purpose of the Act. All meetings of the study commission are open to the public, and interested persons may attend and appear before the commission. The study commission, not subject to FACA, will terminate 3 years after enactment of the Act.
